Literature Review: Structural maintenance of chromosomes (SMC) protein complexes have emerged as crucial players in genome organization and regulation across all domains of life. These evolutionarily conserved motor proteins are responsible for various essential cellular processes, including sister chromatid cohesion, chromosome condensation, and DNA repair. In recent years, the mechanism of DNA loop extrusion by SMC complexes has garnered significant attention as a fundamental process in shaping three-dimensional genome architecture.SMC complexes are composed of two SMC subunits and several non-SMC subunits, forming ring-like structures that can encircle DNA. The three main SMC complexes in eukaryotes are cohesin, condensin, and the Smc5/6 complex, each with distinct but overlapping functions in chromosome biology. Cohesin, for instance, is primarily known for its role in sister chromatid cohesion during cell division, while condensin is essential for chromosome condensation and segregation.The concept of loop extrusion as a mechanism for chromosome organization was first proposed by Nasmyth in 2001, suggesting that SMC complexes could actively create DNA loops by extruding DNA through their ring-like structure. This hypothesis has since gained substantial experimental support, particularly through single-molecule studies that have provided direct evidence of loop extrusion by SMC complexes in vitro.Ganji et al. (2018) demonstrated real-time visualization of DNA loop extrusion by yeast condensin using single-molecule imaging techniques. Their study showed that condensin can extrude DNA loops at a remarkable rate of up to 1,500 base pairs per second, providing the first direct evidence of loop extrusion by an SMC complex. This groundbreaking work was followed by similar observations with human cohesin by Davidson et al. (2019), who showed that cohesin could also extrude DNA loops, albeit at a slower rate than condensin.The mechanistic details of loop extrusion have been further elucidated through a combination of structural, biochemical, and single-molecule approaches. Cryo-electron microscopy studies by Hassler et al. (2019) revealed the structure of the cohesin complex bound to DNA, providing insights into how SMC complexes might engage with and translocate along DNA. These structural studies, combined with biochemical assays, have led to the proposal of various models for the loop extrusion mechanism, including the scrunching model and the pumping model.The energy source for loop extrusion has been a subject of intense investigation. ATP hydrolysis by the SMC subunits is known to be essential for the process, but the exact coupling between ATP hydrolysis and DNA translocation remains unclear. Recent work by Terakawa et al. (2017) suggested that the ATP hydrolysis cycle of condensin is tightly coupled to its DNA-binding and release cycle, providing a potential mechanism for directional movement along DNA.The regulation of SMC complexes and loop extrusion in vivo is another area of active research. Various factors have been identified that can influence the activity of SMC complexes, including CTCF for cohesin and the MukB complex for bacterial SMC. These regulators can affect the processivity, directionality, and positioning of loops, contributing to the specificity of genome organization.The biological consequences of loop extrusion by SMC complexes are far-reaching. In addition to their roles in chromosome condensation and sister chromatid cohesion, loop extrusion has been implicated in the formation of topologically associating domains (TADs) and the regulation of gene expression. Work by Fudenberg et al. (2016) demonstrated that loop extrusion could recapitulate many features of chromosome organization observed in Hi-C data, providing a mechanistic basis for the formation of chromatin domains.Furthermore, the involvement of SMC complexes in DNA repair processes has been increasingly recognized. The Smc5/6 complex, in particular, has been shown to play crucial roles in homologous recombination and the resolution of DNA topological stress during replication. The ability of SMC complexes to bring distant DNA regions into proximity through loop extrusion may facilitate these repair processes.Despite the significant progress in understanding SMC complexes and loop extrusion, many questions remain. The exact molecular mechanism of how SMC complexes translocate along DNA and generate loops is still debated. Additionally, the interplay between different SMC complexes and how their activities are coordinated in vivo are areas that require further investigation.In conclusion, the study of SMC complexes and DNA loop extrusion has revolutionized our understanding of genome organization and regulation. Single-molecule studies have been instrumental in providing direct evidence for loop extrusion and elucidating its mechanistic details. As research in this field continues to advance, we can expect further insights into the fundamental principles governing chromosome biology and their implications for cellular processes and disease states.
